note: See Killean (1972: 151) for modern Arabic. Relative clauses in Proto-Indo-European 231
title: See also examples (12) through (14) below. ίο. The situation is similar in Arabic

provides arguments for defending the proposal that kwi-/kwo- could introduce only restrictive relative clauses. However, the Anatolian and Latin examples that he provides (Hajnal 1997: 59-60) fit better into Grosu’s and De Vries’s maximalizing type

From a syntactic point of view they are correlative clauses - a subtype of the non-reduction strategy according to Comrie 8c Kuteva (2005:§ 122-123) - or preposed relative clauses - a sub­ type of embedded relative clauses in Chr

231) summarizes in a table the positions of relative clauses in regard of the main verb -she points out the fact that preposed relative clauses show up in the earliest attested Indo-Euro­ pean languages and how in some languages generalizing relative clauses are preposed while relative clauses with specific heads are postposed
